title: Slow loading website I visit ONLY on Firefox, and ONLY for me?
content:
I'm having a strange problem with one particular website on my Mac that I hope someone here can solve.

I started having this problem on Wednesday morning of this week.

This is the particular website: https://www.underconsideration.com/brandnew/

It loads incredibly slow for me on my iMac. I'm using the Mojave operating system if that helps.

I contacted their website moderator first and foremost to see if anyone else was having this problem, but he said there are NO other reports. He couldn't offer any help and was also stumped.

Before you offer suggestions, this is what I tried to no avail:

• Restarted Firefox in Safe Mode with ALL plug-ins and extensions turned off • Performed a Refresh on my Firefox browser from scratch • Emptied ALL cache, history and cookies • Unplugged and restarted my Mac, modem and router

Is it a case where I need to delete my Firefox browser and reinstall it?

Is there a corrupt pref file somewhere on my Mac that I got from this website, like Malware?

I know if you visit the website above, it will work perfectly for you, so I really hope someone can help with this strange problem. I'm stumped!!!
creator: stevewiskowski

title: Reset firefox account to default
content:
I recently messed with the privacy and security settings in an attempt to a get a website working on firefox. In the process I must have changed something which now causes to default search engines and bookmarks to disappear every time I start a new session.

When I launch firefox in troubleshoot mode or use the refresh option, it works but only temporarily because once I exit and launch firefox again, I'm back to no search engine.

I've deleted and reinstalled firefox, i've removed .sqlite and .json and meta data files. Everytime, I do this, it resets my browser to it's default state (but with me being signed out of course) so once I sign in, I'm back to no search engine.

Bottom line the problem will remain so long as my profile is set the way that it is and I don't plan on deleting anytime soon so if anyone knows how to reset your firefox account, like start it from scratch, would really appreciate it

title: Can I change the shortcut keys for Ctrl+Alt+Shift+Enter?
content:
Howdy,

When I type in a word into the URL bar and press Ctrl+Enter, FF will add the .com to the end and open the URL. Also, when I type a word into the URL bat and press Alt+Enter, FF will open that word as a URL in a new tab and do a search. However, if I try to combine the two and enter a word in the URL bar and press Ctrl+Alt+Enter, I'd like FF to add the .com and then open it in a new tab but it doesn't (although it works fine in Chrome). Apparently, I have to press Ctrl+Alt+Shift+Enter to get it to do that and that's just a lot of keys.

Is there any way to change a setting somewhere to male Ctrl+Alt+Enter add the .com and open it in a new tab like it should? I don't want to have different key combos between browsers.  ;)

Thanks.

title: Forgetting cookies...?
content:
FF seems to keep forgetting what I call "legitimate" cookies. For example:

  • For websites I use daily without a login, like Accuweather, every few days I get their "Accept our cookies?" messages.
  • For sites that allow an on-going login, I need to re-login frequently. Not daily, but certain not months later.
  • I have a financial site that allows me to set only certain devices may be recognized. Today it said a device I use weekly or so is no longer recognized.

There is an old thread that may be relevant: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1309877

But several issues: That thread is closed, even though this bug is still going. Also it only covers Windows and I could use help with Windows & iOS versions.

Could "Tracking Protection" level come into play? I had it set to Standard but noticed recently it was Strict. I think Firefox changed that, not me, but I can't be 100% positive. Meanwhile I changed it back to Standard but so far the issue remains.

Thank you,

Joe

title: Dictionary in context menu that is not a plugin
content:
Safari and Chrome have a dictionary available in the context menu on Mac. It even translates between languages if you have the right dictionaries installed. In Firefox, the recommendation is to install add-ons as here https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1286892

This approach has problems: 1) these add-ons can "Access your data for all websites" instead of only the word that is highlighted 2) are not available in reader mode nor in PDFs because of limitations in Firefox (see explanation at https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/dictionary-anyvhere/ for example)

Is there any chance that FF can integrate the native dictionary on Mac?

title: Autorefresh of home page causes connection error
content:
I have a website built with Django which generates reports. Whenever I click on a report, I always get a request for the main/home page 3-4 seconds later (note: main page is a redirect to a login page): [27/Aug/2021 10:39:04] INFO Requesting Report [27/Aug/2021 10:39:05] INFO Report generated [27/Aug/2021 10:39:05] "GET /report/ HTTP/1.1" 200 560729

  • [27/Aug/2021 10:39:07] "GET / HTTP/1.1" 302 0
  • [27/Aug/2021 10:39:07] "GET /login/ HTTP/1.1" 200 4395

That request is coming from Firefox (verified by Wireshark) but is not a problem because the report has already been displayed. However, when a report takes longer than 3-4 seconds, I get a connection error: [27/Aug/2021 10:39:09] INFO Requesting Report

  • [27/Aug/2021 10:39:12] "GET / HTTP/1.1" 302 0
  • [27/Aug/2021 10:39:14] "GET /login/ HTTP/1.1" 200 4395

[27/Aug/2021 10:39:26] INFO Report generated

Exception happened during processing of request from ('127.0.0.1', 50681) ConnectionAbortedError: [WinError 10053] An established connection was aborted by the software in your host machine

I can also create this error by adding a 5 second sleep to any report. This does not happen in other browsers, and they do not have the main/home page refresh. The only solution I found online was to set accessibility.blockautorefresh to True. That did not help, the refresh still happens. Is there a way to stop the refresh? Thanks

title: Printing via Firefox V91 prints random characters
content:
I've had this issue since Firefox moved to the new print interface. If the interface appears as the result of the web page I’m currently visiting having an embedded print button, when I print, either via the print interface directly (after clicking on the embedded button in the web page) or from the Firefox menu, the resultant output is nonsense characters. I have two printers, and it’s the same on both. If I save the document as a PDF, it’s correctly formatted and readable. if I print using the simplified output option, it prints correctly, but obviously doesn't look as good and takes up more pages, but it does work.

If I use a different browser (Microsoft Edge & Chrome) it prints correctly. It also prints correctly if a web page has no underlying code specifically for printing. So if I print the page I’m actually entering this issue on, it prints fine. I’ve reset the print settings in Firefox but to no avail.

Any ideas most welcome.

title: cntrl-f search on webpage with cr/lf character
content:
I have a text on a webpage on 2 lines, which are separated by (invisible) instruction to go to the next line (a so-called "cr/lf").

I copy this text (including the cr/lf) from the web page to the clipboard. I activate the search function with "control-f", and I paste this text in the search box, then Firefox finds 0 matches.

for example:

line1 line2

Between line1 and line2 is a CRLF.

So, in above example, on the clipboard there is "line1CRLFline2"

I have the following questions:

1. Is there a way to overcome this? To find correct search result? (1 match) 2. Is there a plugin/extension available that can handle the above scenario?

title: MAR files for Firefox Dev Edition
content:
I found this question from 5 years ago https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1097979 and it looks like the accepted answer still works today for normal releases of Firefox.

e.g. this URL works:

https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-91.0.2-partial-91.0.1&os=win&lang=en-US&force=1

However the URL format for Firefox Developer Edition doesn't seem to accept version strings, so I can't find MARs for devedition

e.g this URL works for devedition: https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-devedition-latest&os=linux64&lang=en-US

But these two don't (the second would be the pattern for a MAR): https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-devedition-92.0b8&os=linux64&lang=en-US https://download.mozilla.org/?product=firefox-devedition-92.0b9-partial-92.0b8&os=linux64&lang=en-US

Presumably MAR files are available for devedition?

title: After smooth scrolling down a PDF, left clicking to stop smooth scrolling makes the PDF skip forward 5-15 pages
content:
I often read books etc in PDF form using the Mozilla reader, and I typically click the scroll wheel to enable smooth scrolling so I don't have to use the wheel to scroll down. However, after I have been doing this for at least a few minutes, there is an 80% or so chance of experiencing a problem. When I left click on the page to disable smooth scrolling, the PDF will flicker and instantly have skipped forward about 10 pages. If I use the right click or scroll wheel to disable smooth scrolling it won't happen, but then left clicking on the page makes it skip ahead the same way. It gets frustrating having to scroll back so frequently, especially if I forgot to note which page I will have to scroll back to

I've tried reinstalling Firefox etc but I can't think of what could be causing this issue and how to fix it as it doesn't seem to be addressed online anywhere

Would be grateful for some help!

title: That 5 Billionth Search Scam
content:
Did a search and clicked https://foreverfuture.net/20x0mox/talking-heads-head-in-the-clouds

Somehow that's not where I went.

Instead the page opened with confetti and I didn't see the URL, but it said I had just conducted the 5 billionth search using Firefox! That seemed unlikely, so I immediately closed the tab.

Then I began to wonder. Had I perhaps actually conducted the 5 billionth search and did a non-profit like Mozilla want to make me wealthy?

So I logged into my Firefox account (had to reset the password). Nothing in my inbox.

Did a search and I am not alone!

I reran the search and clicked again. This time I can see the proper page and it's gibberish. Indexed by Google over a decade(!) ago. Time to report it and run some scans locally.

Fingers crossed.

title: ERROR :  "Hash not found" - with Firefox 91.0, 91.0.1 and 91.0.2.
content:
I always prefer to download updates myself, to then upload each to VirusTotal.com to see what the results are from the many scanners VT uses, before installing any software obtained from over the Internet. VT always begins the upload to the VT website by checking for a hash and this worked prior to Firefox 91.0.x, but has failed for all three updates since the last version before 91.0, so failing for 91.0, 91.0.1 and 91.0.2. The same thing also happens with Thunderbird 91.0.1 from Thunderbird.net, adding this note in case you can communicate regularly with the TBird team.

I'm glad to do the downloads, verifications and installs myself, for if anything ever goes wrong, then I have the downloaded installers to just re-install Ffx. But given that a hash isn't found for the downloaded 91.0.x updates, then I of course wonder what Mozilla is using when performing automatic updates. After all, what we download surely should be what Mozilla uses as well. So, I'll definitely stick to my preferred way of doing updates and definitely hope that this missing hash problem gets corrected very soon.

My current browser is still 90.0.2. It definitely is a "bit" buggy, flaky, often quite annoyingly so, but its hash was found and is still found by VT, so ....
